topic.title: Interlaken <-> MAC <-> FlexE to OTN Datapaths

li.p: Flexible rate frames to Ethernet MAC to FlexE adapted for GMP mapping into OTN (6a).
Flexible rate frames to Ethernet MAC to FlexE for BGMP mapping into OTN (with or without crunching) (6b).

body.p: On the receive path, packets are received over the Interlaken interface, go through the COPI subsystem and stored into the DCPB packet buffer. The MAC provides full PMON while the FEPP_E provides packet insertion and extraction capabilities. The MAC adds the preamble, idles and O/S. Finally the MAC encodes the data into 66b code words. The resulting code word stream then pass through a FLEXE_MUX. The FLEXE_MUX mutliplex these clients into a Flex group. The FlexE group rate is provided by a virtual and nominal rate SERDES.

The FLEXE_MUX will interleave the PHYs into 1 or more subgroups and adapt them for FlexE aware mapping. While doing the interleaving, the FLEXE_MUX can optionally crunch the unavailable timeslots to save bandwidth. The FlexE group/sub-group rate information is derived from the FlexE group rate and is given to the MAPOTN subsystem outside of the ENET. The traffic then pass through the FEMP that performs mapping adaptation functions and forwards it to the ECPB mapping buffer..
The IMP_MAP block within the MAPOTN then extract code words and send them to the OTN BGMP mapper.

In the transmit direction the IMP_MAP block within the MAPOTN performs code word delineation and stores the data into the ECPB demapping buffer. The code words are extracted within the FEDP which performs demapping adaptation functions. The FLEXE_DEMUX will de-interleave the PHYs from 1 or more (sub)groups. While doing the de-interleaving, the FLEXE_DEMUX will restore any timeslots that have been crunched to save bandwidth. The FLEXE_DEMUX terminates the FLexE Group and extract the FlexE clients.

These clients are then pass through the MAC that delineate Ethernet packets, deleting preamble, all idles and O/S. These packets are forwarded and stored into the DCPB packet buffer. The MAC provides full PMON while the FEPP_I provides packet insertion and extraction capabilities. The packets are then extracted from DCPB packet buffer, go through the COPI subsystem and delivered over the Interlaken interface.
